channel.title: Solar panels recycle energy?
channel.description:
I was wondering if for example I want to build a space ship and decide to use solar panels for the floors and have the light come from the lighting around the ship give the panels its energy to support the ship....Can this even work? I was thinking of ways to save energy since I'm on a project of designing a space ship of the future since my goal in life to get us out of this technology age since its so boring!!!!!! lol
So is it possible? the idea came from the idea of minecraft red stone going in a circle if you have it set up in a way it goes around.

item.title: Solar panels recycle energy?
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Not to power the ship entirely. Only with a partial return of energy from the lights. But, as said already, that’s impossible for about ten different reasons

Read full topic

item.title: Solar panels recycle energy?
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:22, topic:535074”][quote author=The Wanderer link=topic=653872.msg4382318#msg4382318 date=1383972993]

Actually I just figured out the biggest hole in this theory

In order to be able to see, light must be reflected off of the object (it doesn’t simply illuminate the area; most of you know this already); thus, by creating walls that would quite literally absorb the light and not reflect it, you would not be able to see anything. So, even if it were possible, there would not technically be lights there anyway.

Lol I wouldn’t say the biggest. I don’t think there is a material that absorbs 100% of light nor do I think that is even possible haha. I think the biggest problem with his theory is that it breaks the laws of physics.
[/quote]
Well, it doesn’t necessarily break the laws of physics. The light would only create outward force, not actual mass, so the spaceship could exist just as regular if it had a strong enough exterior.[/quote]
Using the lights inside of the ship to power the ship? That’s impossible as I stated earlier. Carnot’s theorem says a heat system can only have 100% efficiency meaning at most it can only power the lights not the ship. To power the ship would mean that it would be producing more energy than was put in meaning that it breaks the first law of thermodynamics.

Read full topic

You may look into alcubierres solution to Einstein’s field equations for a proposed method of propulsion…
http://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alcubierre_drive

item.title: Solar panels recycle energy?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

You want to avoid anything adding unnecessary amount of weight on the space ship. So you have to take this into consideration. Do you save weight by adding solar panels to the outside, or is it more efficient with batteries or generating electricity in another way?

And as people have said before, recycling energy doesn’t work. The only thing you can do is to reduce the energy usage.

Loveandpower:

It’s an interesting idea. I don’t know a whole lot about spaceships/science so I am going to go for the “stupid answer” for the topic. Wouldn’t a spaceship go to fast to charge enough sunlight?

It all depends on how you look at it. Every object in the universe is both moving, and not moving at the same time.

Read full topic

item.title: Solar panels recycle energy?
item.dc:creator: @the_wanderer The Wanderer
item.description:
@the_wanderer wrote:

MrFun:

Thanks for your answers it was a simple idea since I know for future space exploration…energy is a problem and was just a idea I was throwing out there. I’m sure it could work if new developments took place on solar panels which then the name would be alter to “something” panel?

It would never work as you can never have more than 100% efficiency in any heat system. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnot's_theorem_(thermodynamics)
Like Wintercanon said, learn the laws of physics. The best you could do is to create 100% efficiency which would mean all you could do is power the lights. You would not be able to use any energy from the lights in the ship to power the ship you would need more energy than you put in which violates a law of thermodynamics.

Read full topic

who told u that lol

item.title: Solar panels recycle energy?
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

Assuming it could work, you wouldn’t have perfect energy recycling. The inefficiency of photovoltaic cells coupled with resistance within electrical systems would yield you probably less than 10% of your original energy used to light the interior.

Read full topic

item.title: Solar panels recycle energy?
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Well, it uses the same concept as a wind field near a space shuttle launch site or a bus going through a wind field tunnel.
As Wintercanon said, it’s unlikely that it emits the correct spectrum of light. If you were to get it to work, it might be functional but in the end not very useful. It’s actually much more useful to just have solar panels on the outside of a ship in space as none of the light is blocked by an atmosphere. Stars would also be within logical distance at most times, though you’d still have to have fuel reserves

Read full topic

item.title: Solar panels recycle energy?
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

Solar panels use energy from a spectrum of light that probably won’t be emitted by the lighting inside the spaceship. In turn, no this cannot work.

Read full topic
